name: sodium dichromate production | sodium dichromate | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/3375/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of sodium dichromate produced by the sulfuric acid process. Sodium dichromate is an inorganic chemical compound that is available as an orange liquid solution or as red-orange crystals. It is used primarily for pigment manufacturing, leather tanning, metals treating.;This dataset is based on literature data.;References:;Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.0 No. 8. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

The activity starts when the raw materials enter the process.

This activity ends with the production of 1 kg of sodium dichromate. The raw materials, the energy and auxillaries input are taken into account together with air emissions and waste. Infrastructure is estimated. No water emissions are taken into account.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Average European value, assumed to be representative of the global production.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Roasting of sodium chromite is accomplished with soda ash and limestone. Sodium chromate is produced, as well as carbon dioxide emissions. The sodium chromate is treated with sulphuric acid and sodium carbonate to produce dichromate and sodium sulfate. The dichromate solution is neutralized to filter the remaining ore residues, which precipitate, then fed to a crystallizer, then to a centrifuge and drier. The post-neutralisation residues are sent to a treatment facility.;This dataset is based on literature data on the acidification process, taken from plant data in Europe and North America.;References:;Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.0 No. 8. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography RER. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data from plants in Europe and North America.

exchanges.description:
Sodium dichromate is an inorganic chemical compound that is available as an orange liquid solution or as red-orange crystals. It is used primarily for pigment manufacturing, leather tanning, metals treating.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.0 No. 8. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

exchanges.description:
According to Chromium (1998), precursor materials in the sulfuric acid process for sodium dichromate production include 1.64 kg of chromite ore.

Reference: 
Adelhardt, W., Antrekowitsch, H.: ”Stoffmengenflüsse und Energiebedarf bei der Gewinnung ausgewählter mineralischer Stoffe – Teilstudie Chrom”, Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe, 1998.

exchanges.description:
According to literature (EPA Dichromate 2000), it can be estimated that 0.47 mg hexavalent chromium is permitted to exit the plant per kg of produced sodium dichromate.

Reference: 
EPA Dichromate 2000, Sodium Dichromate Listing Background Document August 2000

exchanges.description:
According to literature (EPA Dichromate 2000), it can be estimated that 1.2 kg of solid wastes or 55 g of elemental chromium is disposed of per kg of sodium dichromate. These wastes are referred to as reduced chromium treatment residues; they consist of 4.5 wt % chromium (III).

Reference: 
EPA Dichromate 2000, Sodium Dichromate Listing Background Document August 2000

exchanges.description:
According to Chromium (1998),0.3 kg of dust are emitted per kg of product. Assuming the dust figure is pre-treatment, air pollution control devices with an efficiency of 99% would reduce the dust to 0.003 kg / kg product.

Reference: 
Adelhardt, W., Antrekowitsch, H.: ”Stoffmengenflüsse und Energiebedarf bei der Gewinnung ausgewählter mineralischer Stoffe – Teilstudie Chrom”, Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe, 1998.

exchanges.description:
According to literature (EPA Dichromate 2000), total chromium discharges were permitted up to 450 kg per year. Taking production information into account, this amounts to 4 mg chrome (III) emissions per kg of produced sodium dichromate

Reference: 
EPA Dichromate 2000, Sodium Dichromate Listing Background Document August 2000

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.
